title: 114_hr496
content:
The "Alabama Hills National Scenic Area Establishment Act" includes sections on the short title, definitions, establishment of the Alabama Hills National Scenic Area in California, management plan, land trust for Lone Pine Paiute-Shoshone Reservation, transfer of administrative jurisdiction, protection of services and recreational opportunities, and clarification regarding funding. In this Act, key definitions include the management plan, Map, motorized vehicles, National Scenic Area, Secretary, and State. The term "State" refers to California, while "Tribe" refers to the Lone Pine Paiute-Shoshone. "Utility facility" encompasses all current and future water and electric generation facilities, including aqueducts, ditches, electric substations, and communication systems. The curr_chunk describes the various structures and fixtures necessary for the construction, operation, and maintenance of electric generation, storage, and communication circuits for transmitting intelligence and controlling electric energy for various purposes. The curr_chunk focuses on the designation of the Alabama Hills National Scenic Area in California. The Alabama Hills National Scenic Area is established in Inyo County, California, covering approximately 18,610 acres. Its purpose is to conserve and protect significant scenic, cultural, geological, and biological resources for present and future generations. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of the area. The National Scenic Area will be managed by the Secretary as part of the National Landscape Conservation System. The map and legal descriptions filed shall have the same force as if included in the Act, with public availability for inspection in appropriate offices. The Secretary may correct any errors in the map and legal descriptions. The National Scenic Area, managed by the Secretary as part of the National Landscape Conservation System, must be used in a way that preserves resources and values. Activities must comply with relevant laws and support the area's purposes. The National Scenic Area allows existing recreational activities like hiking, biking, climbing, and hunting. Motorized vehicles are only permitted on designated roads and trails for administrative or emergency purposes. Access to the National Scenic Area is limited to designated roads and trails for motorized vehicles, or county-maintained roads. No buffer zones are created around the area, and activities outside the area that can be seen or heard within it are not restricted. The Secretary will provide private landowners access to inholdings in the National Scenic Area. Filming, including commercial production and photography, is allowed with reasonable regulations. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife is not affected by this Act. Livestock grazing, including under the Alabama Hills allotment, is permitted in the National Scenic Area. Livestock grazing in the National Scenic Area, including under the Alabama Hills allotment, is allowed with reasonable regulations and in accordance with applicable laws. Overflights, including transportation, sightseeing, and filming flights, are permitted over the area. The Federal land within the National Scenic Area is withdrawn from various activities, including entry under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. This Act does not prohibit wildland fire operations in cooperation with other entities. The Secretary, in collaboration with other agencies, may conduct wildland fire operations in the National Scenic Area. Grants and cooperative agreements can be made for research, education, and conservation initiatives. The Act does not impact air or water quality standards outside the area. Utility facilities and rights of way are not affected by the Act. The Act allows for maintenance, repair, construction, and other activities related to utility facilities within or near the National Scenic Area, while ensuring minimal impact on the area's purpose. The Management Plan shall establish plans for maintenance of public utility and other rights of way within the National Scenic Area, in accordance with applicable laws and conditions determined by the Secretary. The Management Plan shall establish plans for maintenance of public utility and other rights of way within the National Scenic Area, in accordance with applicable laws and conditions determined by the Secretary. The Secretary must develop a comprehensive plan for the long-term management of the National Scenic Area within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Consultation with various entities is required, and casual-use mining limited to hand tools is allowed in perpetuity. In perpetuity, casual-use mining limited to hand tools, metal detectors, dry washers, vacuum cleaners, gold pans, and small sluices. Interim management by the Secretary in accordance with section 3. SEC. 5. Land taken into trust for Lone Pine Paiute-Shoshone Reservation. The Secretary will take approximately 132 acres of Federal land into trust for the Lone Pine Paiute-Shoshone Tribe, subject to existing conditions and exclusions. The land will be considered part of the Tribe's reservation. Gaming under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act shall not be allowed on the land taken into trust for the Lone Pine Paiute-Shoshone Tribe. SEC. 6. TRANSFER OF ADMINISTRATIVE JURISDICTION: Approximately 56 acres of Federal land are transferred from the Forest Service to the Bureau of Land Management.

SEC. 7. PROTECTION OF SERVICES AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES: Commercial services for recreation uses authorized by the Bureau of Land Management's permit process are not limited. Existing commercial permits for guided recreational opportunities can continue.

SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION REGARDING FUNDING: No additional funds are authorized for implementing this Act and its amendments. The House of Representatives passed this Act on May 23, 2016, with requirements to be carried out using authorized amounts.
